newsitem.title: FRANCE: ATHLETICS-KOFFA BRINGS FURTHER JOY TO GREECE.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-KOFFA BRINGS FURTHER JOY TO GREECE.

text.p: Ekaterina Koffa emulated her compatriot Haralambous Paradias by winning a world sprint title on Saturday at the end of an emotional week for Greece.

Koffa, running from lane six, edged out Jamaica's 1992 Olympic silver medallist Juliet Cuthbert by one- hundredth of a second in the women's 200 metres final on the second day of the world indoor championships.
It was the narrowest victory margin so far in the three-day championships and allowed Koffa to take her place on top of the victory podium the day after Paradias had won the men's 60 metres title.

Greek team members, already delighted by the International Olympic Committee's decision on Friday to put Athens on a shortlist of five candidates to stage the 2004 Games, celebrated noisily, draping Koffa in a Greek flag.
In five previous indoor championships, Greece have gathered just one silver medal.
"The feeling is unbelievable," said Koffa. "I don't think it's difficult to understand, it's the best feeling.
"The sixth lane was the key to my victory, I think it's the best lane."
The men's 200 final went to American Kevin Little, also running from lane six.
Little, who has won two world indoor bronze medals, said: "I think I just proved my worth today. I was fortunate to draw lane six."
Trinidad's Ato Boldon, favourite for the title, pulled up suddenly in the final straight and crumpled to the track.
His coach John Smith jumped down from the stands and watched anxiously as Boldon was carried from the track on a stretcher.
Boldon was later taken to hospital but Smith did not appear too worried.
"Ato felt a contraction at the bottom of his left hamstring at the end of the curve," Smith said. "I don't think that it's important, after two weeks he's going to recover."
Little, who clocked 20.40 seconds, said he had not been surprised by the result.
"I felt I could not be beaten," he said. "It's nice to have a superstar like Boldon in the race, it certainly takes the pressure off."

Second-placed Cuban Ivan Garcia was inititally disqualified for running out of lane but was reinstated after the track referee examined a video recording and decided the infraction had been committed by Boldon.
Moroccan Hicham el Guerrouj ran away with the men's 1,500, although his time of three minutes 35.31 seconds was well outside his own world record of 3:31.18 set early last month.
German Ridger Stenzel was well back in second place ahead of Kenya's 1992 Olympic 800 champion William Tanui.
"It was an easy race for me," said el Guerrouj. "I have had a sensational start to this year and I hope there's more to come. This could be my year."
Inna Lasovskaya of Russia took the women's triple jump with a leap of 15.01 metres, only two centimetres outside the world record.
"Paris was always my favourite town and Bercy my favourite track," said Lasovakaya.

The women's 3,000 metres, the final track event of the evening, was won in a thrilling sprint finish by Romania's defending champion Gabriela Szabo who overhauled Irishwoman Sonia O'Sullivan over the final metres to win in 8:45.75.

Cuban Ivan Pedroso, whose season last year was disrupted by injury, won the men's long jump title while Olympic and world champion Stefka Kostadinova showed her competitive steel by winning a tense women's high jump final.
Kostadinova leaped a year's best of 2.02 then made three unsuccessful attempts on the world record of 2.07.
